natural problem: Of the 50 students in the drama club, 36 take mathematics, 27 take physics and 20 students take both mathematics and physics. How many drama club students take neither mathematics nor physics?
natural solution: Of the 36 taking math, there are 20 taking both math and physics, so there are $36-20= 16$ students taking only math.

Similarly, there are $27-20= 7$ taking only physics. There are 50 students total, 16 in just math, 7 in just physics, and 20 in both math and physics, so there are  $50-16-7-20= \boxed{7}$ students taking neither.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes drama_students math_students physics_students both_students :: nat
assumes h0 : "drama_students = 50"
and h1 : "math_students = 36"
and h2 : "physics_students = 27"
and h3 : "both_students = 20"
shows  "drama_students - math_students - physics_students + both_students = 7"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Of the 50 students in the drama club, 36 take mathematics, 27 take physics and 20 students take both mathematics and physics. How many drama club students take neither mathematics nor physics? The final Answer is 7
 ### Proof
 Of the 36 taking math, there are 20 taking both math and physics, so there are $36-20= 16$ students taking only math.
 Similarly, there are $27-20= 7$ taking only physics. There are 50 students total, 16 in just math, 7 in just physics, and 20 in both math and physics, so there are  $50-16-7-20= \boxed{7}$ students taking neither.
 *)

theorem
fixes drama_students math_students physics_students both_students :: nat
assumes h0 : "drama_students = 50"
and h1 : "math_students = 36"
and h2 : "physics_students = 27"
and h3 : "both_students = 20"
shows  "drama_students - math_students - physics_students + both_students = 7"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: There are 50 students enrolled in drama, 36 students enrolled in math and 27 students enrolled in physics. If 20 students are enrolled in both math and physics, how many more students are enrolled in drama than the combined total of math and physics students? The final answer is 7.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes total_students math_students physics_students both_students :: nat
assumes h0 : "total_students = 50"
and h1 : "math_students = 36"
and h2 : "physics_students = 27"
and h3 : "both_students = 20"
shows  "total_students - (math_students + physics_students - both_students) = 7"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem

 Similarly, there are $27-20= 7$ taking only physics. There are 50 students total, 16 in just math, 7 in just physics, and 20 in both math and physics, so there are  $50-16-7-20= \boxed{7}$ students taking neither.
 *)

theorem
fixes total_students math_students physics_students both_students :: nat
assumes h0 : "total_students = 50"
and h1 : "math_students = 36"
and h2 : "physics_students = 27"
and h3 : "both_students = 20"
shows  "total_students - (math_students + physics_students - both_students) = 7"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: "In a class of 50 students, 36 students take mathematics, 27 students take physics, and 20 students take both subjects. How many students don't take either of the subjects? The final answer is 7."
